docs.snippet: ''SOME ENCHANTED EVENING,'' the third Rodgers and Hammerstein salute in the long-running ''King Cole Loves Broadway'' series at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel, is the liveliest show yet in the four-year existence of the series. Given an enlarged sta...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''SOME ENCHANTED EVENING,'' the third Rodgers and Hammerstein salute in the long-running ''King Cole Loves Broadway'' series at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel, is the liveliest show yet in the four-year existence of the series. Given an enlarged stage, a new choreographer, Barbara Siman Strouse, has physically loosened up the production.

docs.snippet: Emma (Sweet Emma) Barrett, a jazz pianist, died here Friday morning after she suffered a stroke Thursday. She was 85 years old.   She was a star at Preservation Hall, the prime spot in New Orleans to hear traditional New Orleans jazz. She played h...
docs.lead_paragraph: Emma (Sweet Emma) Barrett, a jazz pianist, died here Friday morning after she suffered a stroke Thursday. She was 85 years old. She was a star at Preservation Hall, the prime spot in New Orleans to hear traditional New Orleans jazz. She played her last engagement there Jan. 18.

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

headline.main: Malcolm Dixon to Be Wed To Elizabeth A. Mortimer

docs.snippet: BLACK SHEEP. By Christopher Simon Sykes. 285 pages. Illustrated. Viking.  $17.75.   ''I THINK it is my duty to put you in mind,'' wrote Lady Mary Wortley Montagu to her husband in 1741, ''that in so near a relation as that of father and son, there...
docs.lead_paragraph: BLACK SHEEP. By Christopher Simon Sykes. 285 pages. Illustrated. Viking. $17.75. ''I THINK it is my duty to put you in mind,'' wrote Lady Mary Wortley Montagu to her husband in 1741, ''that in so near a relation as that of father and son, there is no medium between a thorough displeasure and a thorough reconciliation.'' This lack of a medium was never a problem for Lady Mary and her husband, who remained absolute in their displeasure with their son Edward, whose life encompassed every crime from bigamy and theft to the publishing of a book that his mother considered ''nonsensical.''

docs.snippet: JAZZ tends to hibernate in small, crowded cellar clubs and lofts during the winter, with occasional concerts as a change of pace. With the coming of summer and the Kool Jazz Festival, the music bursts into the concert halls and the streets, shakes...
docs.lead_paragraph: JAZZ tends to hibernate in small, crowded cellar clubs and lofts during the winter, with occasional concerts as a change of pace. With the coming of summer and the Kool Jazz Festival, the music bursts into the concert halls and the streets, shakes the cold out of its bones and begins to strut. At least, that's been the routine in recent years. It's a routine Lehman College's first Midwinter Jazz Festival aims to shake up a bit. Tonight, tomorrow and Sunday, Benny Goodman, Stan Getz, Gary Burton, Oscar Peterson and other leading jazz musicians will be heard in two evening and three afternoon programs in the comfortable, modern concert hall and theater of Lehman College's Center for the Performing Arts. The center, on Beford Park Boulevard West in the Bronx, offers amenities of a kind not usually encountered by those out listening to jazz - buffet dining with music beginning at 5:30 P.M. today and tomorrow, for example, and free parking in an attended lot. Lehman College's regular jazz program has been making a reputation for itself for several years, especially because it provides a place for musicians to learn about the nuts and bolts of jazz improvising.

headline.main: A VARIED WEEKEND FOR MUSICAL ADVENTURING

docs.snippet: IN ''The Modern Ladies of Guanabacoa,'' which opened last night at the Ensemble Studio Theater, the playwright Eduardo Machado wants to show us just how Cuba was dragged kicking and screaming into the 20th century.   Though his work is intimate in...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN ''The Modern Ladies of Guanabacoa,'' which opened last night at the Ensemble Studio Theater, the playwright Eduardo Machado wants to show us just how Cuba was dragged kicking and screaming into the 20th century. Though his work is intimate in scale, the tale it implicitly tells is of epic historical dimensions, involving sweeping political, economic, social and religious change. There's probably enough potential material here for a dozen plays, and, as it happens, at least two of them seem to be uneasily jammed, one per act, into ''Modern Ladies.'' But if Mr. Machado is a young writer in too much of a hurry to get everything off his chest at once, there's no question that he has talent.

headline.main: STAGE: 'MODERN LADIES OF GUANABACOA,' CUBA IN '28

docs.snippet: LOS ANGELES B ack in drama class, our professor used to say the best theater came when somebody was trying to do something and somebody else was trying to stop it. It sounds pretty simple, but that's exactly what this Super Bowl needs - a little d...
docs.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES B ack in drama class, our professor used to say the best theater came when somebody was trying to do something and somebody else was trying to stop it. It sounds pretty simple, but that's exactly what this Super Bowl needs - a little drama. We need King Lear, we need Hedda Gabler, we need somebody trying to impose a game plan on the universe. We need Blanche DuBois at running back, trying to move in; we need Stanley Kowalski at linebacker, trying to evict her.

docs.snippet: A Turk wanted by Italian magistrates on suspicion of complicity in the shooting of Pope John Paul II says he has never met the man who shot the Pontiff in 1981.   But the Turk, Bekir Celenk, did say in an interview that he had been in Bulgaria at ...
docs.lead_paragraph: A Turk wanted by Italian magistrates on suspicion of complicity in the shooting of Pope John Paul II says he has never met the man who shot the Pontiff in 1981. But the Turk, Bekir Celenk, did say in an interview that he had been in Bulgaria at the same time that Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turk convicted of shooting the Pope, was reportedly there. Unconfirmed reports in Italian newspapers have said that Mr. Celenk offered Mr. Agca $1.25 million in German marks on behalf of the Bulgarian secret service to shoot the Pope. Two Bulgarian officials who served in the country's embassy in Rome and who are wanted for questioning in connection with the shooting of John Paul denied any involvement in the assassination attempt. (Page A8.)

headline.main: TURK SOUGHT BY ITALY SAYS HE NEVER MET MAN WHO SHOT POPE

docs.snippet: George Cukor, a director whose career spanned 53 years and whose films were distinguished by grace, style, taste and unpretentious sophistication, died in Los Angeles on Monday. He was 83 years old.   The scrupulously detailed craftsmanship of his...
docs.lead_paragraph: George Cukor, a director whose career spanned 53 years and whose films were distinguished by grace, style, taste and unpretentious sophistication, died in Los Angeles on Monday. He was 83 years old. The scrupulously detailed craftsmanship of his many artistic and commercial successes appealed to wide audiences for decades and his more than 50 movies included an extraordinary range of urbane entertainments. Mr. Cukor is ''one of the most elegant directors Hollywood has ever produced,'' Vincent Canby, film critic of The New York Times, wrote in 1976. Worked With Top Stars Mr. Cukor was celebrated for bringing out the best in performers. His films include a roster of most of Hollywood's major actresses in some of their finest performances. There are Katharine Hepburn in ''Little Women'' (1933) and ''The Philadelphia Story'' (1940), among many others; Norma Shearer in ''Romeo and Juliet'' (1936); Greta Garbo in ''Camille'' (1937); Joan Crawford in ''A Woman's Face'' (1941); Ingrid Bergman in ''Gaslight'' (1944); Judy Holliday in ''Born Yesterday'' (1950) and ''The Marrying Kind'' (1952); Judy Garland in ''A Star Is Born'' (1954); Ava Gardner in ''Bhowani Junction'' (1956) and Audrey Hepburn in ''My Fair Lady'' (1964).
